findings.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

findings.description: Spell out numbers below 100 in non-technical writing (Amida Style Guide p.5)
findings.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

findings.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

findings.found_text: The disease_related_codes function determines whether a given code description is directly or indirectly related to a specified VASRD disease (e.g., Sarcoidosis). It evaluates direct mentions, known manifestations, complications, affected organs, inflammatory conditions, symptoms, and treatments. The function returns “yes” if related, otherwise “no,” enforcing a strict binary output.

findings.description: Use commas for numbers of 4+ digits (Amida Style Guide p.5)
findings.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections

findings.description: Use commas for numbers of 4+ digits (Amida Style Guide p.5)
findings.found_text: Figure 30 -  Cosine similarity analysis was implemented to quantify the textual relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions. The computed similarity scores exhibited a range from 0.6876 to 0.8870 in the API output results, while Hannah's codes demonstrated scores from 0.7099 to 0.8870. Although cosine similarity excels at measuring textual alignment between vector representations, the substantial overlap in score distributions suggests its limitations in distinctly separating the approved codes from the broader API output set. This overlap presents a significant challenge in reliably identifying and ranking the 147 validated codes within the top 500 results.

findings.description: Use commas for numbers of 4+ digits (Amida Style Guide p.5)
findings.found_text: Figure 32 -  In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from 0.4754 to 0.7904 in the API dataset and 0.4754 to 0.7617 in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

findings.found_text: This image displays Step 3 of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. The "Filtered Clinical Codes" section presents a table of ICD-10 codes that have been identified as relevant to the disease(Sarcoidosis, VASRD code 6846). In this final step, the keywords generated in Step 2 are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.

3.description: Spell out numbers below 100 in non-technical writing (Amida Style Guide p.5)
3.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

4.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

11.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

40.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections

word_list.description: Apply Amida Word List preferences (Amida Style Guide p.5-6)
word_list.found_text: This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.

word_list.description: Apply Amida Word List preferences (Amida Style Guide p.5-6)
word_list.found_text: This diagram illustrates the VACM ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted from eCFR data, as shown in the above figure, and processed through an LLM to generate relevant medical keywords such as "Echocardiography," "Prednisone," and "Complete blood count." The expanded keywords are then mapped to standardized medical codes using the UMLS API, resulting in ICD-10 codes (e.g., R50.9 for Fever), CPT codes (e.g., 93306 for Echocardiography), RxNorm codes (e.g., 8640 for Prednisone), and LOINC codes (e.g., 718-7 for Complete Blood Count).

word_list.description: Apply Amida Word List preferences (Amida Style Guide p.5-6)
word_list.found_text: Expansion Prompt Template: Extracts comprehensive medical knowledge, from anatomical to pathological aspects, for specific diseases and conditions. The prompt focuses on six key areas: pathological process, anatomical involvement, clinical manifestations, diagnostic indicators, disease progression, and treatment response, including specific anatomical locations and systems (e.g., “Lungs, Heart, Brain, Ocular” instead of “Primary organs affected”). This template accepts disease names to capture multi-system involvement and broader medical terminology. Its structured format generates detailed medical analysis across primary mechanisms, organ systems, symptoms, diagnostic markers, progression patterns, and treatment outcomes. This approach enables more precise code mapping and captures the full spectrum of anatomical involvement in conditions (Example: Sarcoidosis).

It evaluates direct mentions, known manifestations, complications, affected organs, inflammatory conditions, symptoms, and treatments. The function returns “yes” if related, otherwise “no,” enforcing a strict binary output.

numerals_commas.description: Use commas for numbers of 4+ digits (Amida Style Guide p.5)
numerals_commas.found_text: Figure 29– This stacked bar chart compares the performance of four embedding models - text-embedding-ada-002, BioBERT, PubMedBERT, and all-MiniLM-L6-v2 - in aligning ICD-10 code descriptions with the ECFR description of VASRD Code: 6846 (Sarcoidosis) using cosine similarity. Each bar represents 147 ICD-10 codes split into 'Matched Codes' (blue) and 'Missing Codes' (dark blue). text-embedding-ada-002 achieved 33 matches, all-MiniLM-L6-v2 had 28 matches, while BioBERT and PubMedBERT each matched only 1 code. PubMedBERT and BioBERT yielded fewer matches in the top 200 results because their embeddings focus on biomedical text, which may not align well with the regulatory and clinical language in the ECFR description, resulting in weaker semantic connections

numerals_commas.found_text: Figure 30 -  Cosine similarity analysis was implemented to quantify the textual relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions. The computed similarity scores exhibited a range from 0.6876 to 0.8870 in the API output results, while Hannah's codes demonstrated scores from 0.7099 to 0.8870. Although cosine similarity excels at measuring textual alignment between vector representations, the substantial overlap in score distributions suggests its limitations in distinctly separating the approved codes from the broader API output set. This overlap presents a significant challenge in reliably identifying and ranking the 147 validated codes within the top 500 results.

numerals_commas.found_text: Figure 32 -  In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from 0.4754 to 0.7904 in the API dataset and 0.4754 to 0.7617 in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

numerals_commas.found_text: This image displays Step 3 of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. The "Filtered Clinical Codes" section presents a table of ICD-10 codes that have been identified as relevant to the disease(Sarcoidosis, VASRD code 6846). In this final step, the keywords generated in Step 2 are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.
